content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to the analysis of <math alttext="C a B r 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaBr</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) A student has a <math alttext="10.0 gram"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="C a B r 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaBr</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the setup of the calculation to determine the number of moles of <math alttext="C a B r 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaBr</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the sample. Include units in the setup. (You do not need to do any calculations.)

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to the analysis of <math alttext="C a B r 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaBr</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(a) A student has a <math alttext="10.0 gram"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="C a B r 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaBr</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the setup of the calculation to determine the number of moles of <math alttext="C a B r 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaBr</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in the sample. Include units in the setup. (You do not need to do any calculations.)

(b) What number, in addition to the answer to part <math alttext="(a)"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(a)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is needed to determine the number of atoms of <math alttext="C a"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in the sample?

(c) A different student is given a <math alttext="10.0 gram"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample labeled <math alttext="C a B r 2"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaBr</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that may contain an inert (nonreacting) impurity. Identify a quantity from the results of laboratory analysis that the student could use to determine whether the sample was pure.

(d) Explain why <math alttext="C a C l 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaCl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is likely to have properties similar to those of <math alttext="C a B r 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CaBr</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 4.C: Explain the connection between particulate-level and macroscopic properties of a substance using models and representations.
